sentences: Alice Glass (born Margaret Osborn, 23 August 1988) is a Canadian singer and songwriter.
She is the co-founder and former frontwoman of the electronic band Crystal Castles.
In 2014, she embarked on a solo career.
She released her eponymous debut EP in 2017.
Her solo debut album, Prey//IV, is due to be released in February 2022.
Life and career ==

section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: Alice Glass was born Margaret Osborn on 23 August 1988 in Toronto, Ontario.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: She was raised Catholic, attending parochial school up until junior high.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: At age 15, she ran away from home to live in a squat community of punks under the name Vicki Vale (after the comic book character) and started an all-girl experimental punk band called Fetus Fatale.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: In December 2003, she and Ethan Kath began working together on the project that would become Crystal Castles.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: She picked the stage name Alice Glass based on a pin with the name Alice that she shoplifted and Hopey Glass, a character in Love and Rockets.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: Crystal Castles' first official release was their 2006 single "Alice Practice".
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: The song got the band their first record deal with Merok Records in London.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: The same year, Crystal Castles played their first live show at Clinton's Tavern in Toronto.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: "Alice Practice" was eventually featured on their eponymous debut album released in 2008.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: Glass topped NME's Cool List that year and responded to it by criticizing the idea of the cool list itself.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: The duo followed their debut album with two more critically acclaimed albums, II (2010) and III (2012), completing a trilogy.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: Glass co-wrote every Crystal Castles song she contributed vocals to.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: In October 2014, Glass announced her departure from Crystal Castles due to her own professional and personal reasons.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: In the announcement, she noted that working within the band compromised her efforts towards "sincerity, honesty, and empathy for others".
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===

sentences: She later had a number of public disagreements with her former bandmate, including accusing him of assault and sexual misconduct.
section: == Life and career == | === 1988–2014: Early life and Crystal Castles ===
== Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===
== Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: In July 2015, Glass released her debut single as a solo artist, "Stillbirth".
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: The release was largely an effort to increase awareness of domestic and sexual abuse.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: Glass worked with anti-sexual assault organization RAINN to donate all proceeds from the song's revenue to aid abuse victims.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: In August 2017, Glass released "Without Love", which served as the lead single to her eponymous debut EP which was released the following week.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: She headed on tour with Marilyn Manson following the release of the EP.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: In October 2017, Glass posted a statement on her official website explaining her departure from Crystal Castles, accusing co-founder Ethan Kath of sexual, physical, and mental abuse.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: The accusations detail the abuse starting when Glass was 15 and began recording with Kath and escalated until her eventual departure from Crystal Castles.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: Kath responded the same day in a statement issued to Pitchfork through his attorney, where he called the accusations "pure fiction" and said he was consulting with his lawyers as to his legal options.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: The following month, Kath sued Glass for defamation, but was dismissed in February 2018.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: In May, Glass was awarded nearly US$21,000 in attorney fees after Kath's lawyers sought to vacate the dismissal of his defamation lawsuit against Glass.
section: == Life and career == | === 2015–2017: Alice Glass and lawsuit ===

sentences: In January 2018, Glass released "Forgiveness" as the second single from her EP.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: She also released that month a brand new single called "Cease and Desist", which she said "is a call to arms for all survivors."
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: Both singles were accompanied by music videos.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: In April 2018, Glass embarked on her SnowBlood Tour alongside American singer Zola Jesus, with electronic musician Pictureplane being an opening act on select dates.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: The tour is named after Lady Snowblood, spurned star of the eponymous 1973 Japanese film.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: Later that month, Glass released a remix EP, consisting of remixes of songs from her eponymous EP released in 2017.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: The EP includes remixes from both Zola Jesus and Pictureplane.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: In June 2018, Glass released a new single, "Mine", accompanied by a music video directed by Lucas David and starring American drag queen Violet Chachki.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: In December, Glass was featured on Adult Swim's singles series with a new song titled "I Trusted You".
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: In 2020, Glass revealed that she received little royalties from her work in Crystal Castles.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: She disavowed her tenure in the band and asked fans to cease their support of the group.
section: == Life and career == | === 2018–2020: Non-album single releases ===

sentences: 2021–present:
Prey//IV ===
Glass released the single "Suffer and Swallow" on 6 January 2021, which was the first song she shared from her long-awaited solo debut album which she said was to be released later that year.
The song was accompanied by a stop-motion music video by Lucas David.
She had a guest appearance on Alice Longyu Gao's single "Legend" which was released on 27 May 2021.
On 19 November 2021, Glass unveiled the title and shared the track listing of her solo debut album Prey//IV and announced a release date of 28 January 2022 by her own Eating Glass Records.
The announcement was accompanied the single "Baby Teeth", which had by a music video by Astra Zero and Lucas David.
On 8 December 2021, Glass premiered the single "Fair Game" accompanied by a music video directed by Bryan M. FergusonOn 28 January 2022, Glass released "Love Is Violence".
The single was accompanied by a gory music video by Bryan M. Ferguson.
The early 2000's inspired video depicts two teenagers who sensually pull out each other's entrails.
Live performances ==
Glass is known for her dedication to performing.

In March 2008, she broke two ribs from an altercation with her tour manager, when she hit a monitor at a 90-degree angle, and continued to tour, performing a 20-minute set within days of the accident despite instruction from doctors to take six weeks off to heal.
In January 2011, Glass performed five months' worth of shows on crutches after falling and putting a strain on an unhealed ankle injury.
At the 2013 Glastonbury Festival, Crystal Castles began their set 20 minutes past the scheduled time, with Glass visibly sick and beginning "Plague" sitting with her head in her hands.
According to NME, Glass had been suffering from food poisoning, but chose to perform anyway.
Crystal Castles was infamously shut down at Glastonbury 2008 after Glass climbed a speaker stand just before "Alice Practice" and was swallowed by the crowd during "Yes No".
